title: Lesson 16: Staining Techniques and Cell Viability Assays
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding staining techniques for microscopy and cell viability assays including trypan blue exclusion and calculation of viability percentages.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the purpose of staining in light microscopy (contrast/identification) and name two common stains.
Students can distinguish between viable and non-viable cells using simple assays (trypan blue exclusion).
Students can interpret data from cell viability assays to determine proliferation rates.

prerequisites.description: Cell culture—need to assess cell health

engagementHook.title: Dead or Alive?
engagementHook.content: 'How do scientists know if their cultured cells are healthy before testing a new drug on them? They can't just ask. Instead, they use colour-changing assays that act like cellular 'vital signs.' Blue means dead, clear means alive, purple means metabolically active. Today we explore the staining techniques that make the invisible visible and the assays that separate the living from the dead.'

keyConcepts.definition: Living cells are mostly transparent; stains add colour/contrast to structures. Basic stains (methylene blue, crystal violet, iodine) bind acidic components (DNA). Acidic stains (eosin) bind basic components (cytoplasm).
Differential stain for bacteria (peptidoglycan wall retains crystal violet in Gram-positive; pink safranin in Gram-negative). Connects to Lesson 1 (cell wall differences).
Trypan blue (dead cells with damaged membranes take up blue dye; live cells exclude it). Metabolic assays (MTT—viable cells with active mitochondria reduce yellow dye to purple).
Hemocytometer (counting chamber); calculating concentration (cells per mL) and viability percentage (live/total × 100).

misconceptions.correction: Some do (fixative stains), but vital stains (trypan blue) are used specifically to test if cells are already dead. Live cells exclude the dye.

misconceptions.misconception: All cells stain the same colour
misconceptions.correction: Different structures take up different stains (Gram staining differentiates bacteria by wall type).
They measure membrane integrity (trypan) or metabolic activity (MTT), not physical dimensions.

contentSections.title: Why Stain Cells?
contentSections.content: Living cells are transparent (water + proteins). Stains bind specific structures to create contrast. Methylene blue stains nuclei (acidic DNA). Iodine stains starch/carbohydrates (glycogen in animal cells, starch in plants).
contentSections.example: Gram staining in hospital labs—rapid identification of bacterial infection type (Gram-positive purple = Staph; Gram-negative pink = E. coli).

contentSections.title: Trypan Blue Viability Assay
contentSections.content: Side-by-side cells: Live cell (clear/white, membrane intact, dye excluded) vs Dead cell (blue, membrane compromised, dye entered).
keyPoints: Live cells have intact membranes that exclude large dye molecules
contentSections.example: Counting live cells for cancer drug testing—only viable cells matter for drug response.

contentSections.title: Calculating Viability
contentSections.content: Step-by-step calculation of cell viability percentage.
contentSections.problem: In a hemocytometer count, 100 cells are seen. 85 exclude trypan blue (clear), 15 take up trypan blue (blue). What is the viability percentage?
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why don't we count the blue cells as viable? (Membrane is compromised/dead).

multipleChoice.question: In a trypan blue exclusion assay, live cells appear colourless because they:
options: Have intact membranes that prevent dye entry
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Have intact membranes that prevent dye entry
multipleChoice.rationale: Membrane integrity test. Live cells exclude the dye; dead cells with compromised membranes take it up.

multipleChoice.question: Which stain would be most appropriate for distinguishing between Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria?
multipleChoice.rationale: Specific application of Gram stain. Differential stain based on cell wall composition.

shortAnswer.question: Explain why staining is necessary when viewing cells under a light microscope, and identify one specific cellular component that methylene blue stains. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Living cells are transparent/low contrast; stains add colour/make structures visible
1 mark: Methylene blue stains the nucleus/nucleic acids/DNA (or acidic structures)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying stains 'feed' cells or help them grow.

shortAnswer.question: A researcher counts 50 cells in a hemocytometer. Ten cells appear blue with trypan blue stain, while 40 remain colourless. Calculate the percentage viability of the cell culture. (1 mark)

definitions: Stains add contrast to transparent cells for light microscopy.
Gram stain differentiates bacteria by cell wall type (Gram-positive purple, Gram-negative pink).
Trypan blue assay: dead cells take up dye (blue), live cells exclude it (clear).
keyPoints: Living cells are transparent - need stains for contrast

shortAnswer: Staining is necessary because living cells are mostly transparent (composed primarily of water and proteins), making them difficult to see under a light microscope without added contrast. Stains bind to specific cellular structures and add colour, making the cells and their components visible. Methylene blue is a basic stain that specifically stains acidic structures, particularly the nucleus and nucleic acids (DNA).
Percentage viability = (Live cells / Total cells) × 100 = (40 / 50) × 100 = 80% viable.
